232011 methanex responsible care and social responsibility report
The addition of a signiﬁ  cant number of new employees 
in Egypt and Canada, coupled with a decrease in qualiﬁ  ed 
and experienced contractors, has had an impact on our safety performance. 
To address the shortage of experienced contractors, 
we are working with technical education providers to establish programs that will equip workers with the skills and knowledge they need to succeed in this work environment. One example is the “Be Safe, Taranaki” program in New Zealand, where local industry, including Methanex, provides funding to support a health, safety and environment curriculum for prospective new workers. The New Zealand Qualiﬁ  cation Authority oversees the 
quality of the course materials and instruction. 
Although these initiatives are still in the early stages, 
we are conﬁ  dent that they will improve contractors’ 
technical skills and job safety. We have also taken spe-ciﬁ c lessons learned from contractor-related incidents 
and changed how we manage contractors at our sites. These changes are now reﬂ  ected in our Contractor Re-
sponsible Care Standard to ensure that this knowledge is embedded across the company.
